g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
. The major nuclear accidents (i.e. Three Mile Island,
Chernobyl, and Fukushima) decreased public support
public remains concerned about the safet
of nuclear power plants and radioactive materials
(Tsujikawa et al. 2016; Bird et al. 2014; Pampel 2011)
At the same time, some groups see nuclear
energy as a reliable energy source, beneficial for the economy and helpful in climate change mitigation.
Public support for nuclear energy is higher when
people are concerned about energy security, including
concerns about the availability of energy and high energy prices
and when they expect local benefit
. Public support also increases when trust in
making processes enhance perceived procedural fairness and public support
Because of the sheer scale of the investment required (individual projects can exceed
value), nearly 90% of nuclear power plants under construction are run by state
companies with governments assuming significant part of the risks and costs. For countries that choose
nuclear power in their energy portfo
table political conditions and support, clear regulatory regimes,
and adequate financial framework are crucial for successful and efficient implementation.
policies influence the competitiveness of nuclear power. For example, feed
premiums for renewables widely applied in the EU
low or even negative prices), which affects the revenues of existing nuclear and other plants

term solution to spent nuclear fuel. Evidence from countries steadily progressing towards first
uggests that broad political support, coherent nuclear
Proliferation concerns surrounding nuclear power are related
to fuel cycle (i.e., uranium enrichment and spent fuel processing). These processes are implemented in
a very limited number of countries following strict national and internation
als norms and rules, such as
IAEA guidelines, treaties, and conventions. Most of the countries which might introduce nuclear power
in the future for their climate change mitigation benefits do not envision developing their own full fuel
y reducing any risks that might be linked to proliferation
Carbon Dioxide Capture, Utilization, and Storage
re have been increased efforts to develop novel platforms that reduce the energy penalty
utilization pathways as a substitute to geologic storage, and
establish global policies to support CCS (
can be used within electricity and other
sectors. While it increases the costs of electricity, CCS has the potential to contribute significantly to
The theoretical global geologic storage potential is about 10,000 Gt
). Not all the storage capacity is usable because
geologic and engineering factors limit the actual storage capacity to an order of magnitude below the
theoretical potential, which is still more than the CO
is the global distribution of storage capacity
Most of the available storage capacity exists in saline aquifers. Capacity in oil and gas
Storage potential in the U.S. alone is >1,000 Gt
. The Middle East has more than 50% of global enhanced oil
. It is likely that oil and gas reservoirs will be developed
